questions.question_text: Which blade should you instruct the finance department auditors to use?

discussion.content:
I think the "Cost Analysis" is the right answer.
Invoices are issued on a monthly basis, while the requirement is to view the cost related to the last week. It can be done only with Cost Analysis.

questions.answer_description:
You can opt in and configure additional recipients to receive your Azure invoice in an email. This feature may not be available for certain subscriptions such as support offers, Enterprise Agreements, or Azure in Open.
1. Select your subscription from the Subscriptions page. Opt-in for each subscription you own. Click Invoices then Email my invoice.

2. Click Opt in and accept the terms.
Scenario: During the testing phase, auditors in the finance department must be able to review all Azure costs from the past week.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/billing/billing-download-azure-invoice-daily-usage-date

choices.A: From the Groups blade, invite the user accounts to a new group.
choices.B: From the Profile blade, modify the usage location.
choices.C: From the Directory role blade, modify the directory role.

questions.answer_description:
License cannot be assigned to a user without a usage location specified.

Scenario: Licensing Issue -
You attempt to assign a license in Azure to several users and receive the following error message: "Licenses not assigned. License agreement failed for one user."
You verify that the Azure subscription has the available licenses.
questions.question_text:
You need to resolve the licensing issue before you attempt to assign the license again.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
So this is one of those stupid MSOFT questions that dont give you enough info but basically 

https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/users-groups-roles/licensing-groups-resolve-problems

The only one that fits the bill out of options is 
Usage location isn't allowed
Problem: Some Microsoft services aren't available in all locations because of local laws and regulations. Before you can assign a license to a user, you must specify the Usage location property for the user. You can specify the location under the User > Profile > Settings section in the Azure portal.

When Azure AD attempts to assign a group license to a user whose usage location isn't supported, it fails and records an error on the user.

To solve this problem, remove users from unsupported locations from the licensed group. Alternatively, if the current usage location values don't represent the actual user location, you can modify them so that the licenses are correctly assigned next time (if the new location is supported).

PowerShell: PowerShell cmdlets report this error as ProhibitedInUsageLocationViolation.

choices.C: From the Azure Active Directory blade, modify the Properties.
choices.A: From the Subscriptions blade, select the subscription, and then modify the Properties.
choices.D: From the Azure Active Directory blade, modify the Groups.
choices.B: From the Subscriptions blade, select the subscription, and then modify the Access control (IAM) settings.

questions.question_text:
You need to meet the user requirement for Admin1.
What should you do?
questions.answer_description:
Change the Service administrator for an Azure subscription
1. Sign in to Account Center as the Account administrator.
2. Select a subscription.
3. On the right side, select Edit subscription details.
Scenario: Designate a new user named Admin1 as the service administrator of the Azure subscription.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/billing/billing-add-change-azure-subscription-administrator

discussion.content:
All answers are actually wrong 
https://www.msb365.blog/?p=83
Yes in Subscriptions Balde -> Properties you can see the service admin and it looks like their is a button to change it but the button can never be clicked! Has to be done from the management portal. So for the Best Wrong answer its Subscriptions->Properties
A & D would both work here. D is the cleaner, more "admin like" solution though.

The main point to use File explorer is: Copy the blueprint files to Azure over the Internet.
Azure Import / Export Service is also possible to send data to Storage blob, but it will be a move on a physical hard drive shipped to a Microsoft Datacenter, and not internet.

questions.answer_description:
Azure Storage Explorer is a free tool from Microsoft that allows you to work with Azure Storage data on Windows, macOS, and Linux. You can use it to upload and download data from Azure blob storage.
Scenario:
Planned Changes include: move the existing product blueprint files to Azure Blob storage.
Technical Requirements include: Copy the blueprint files to Azure over the Internet.
References:
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/machine-learning/team-data-science-process/move-data-to-azure-blob-using-azure-storage-explorer
questions.question_text:
You need to move the blueprint files to Azure.
What should you do?

choices.A: Generate a shared access signature (SAS). Map a drive, and then copy the files by using File Explorer.
choices.C: Generate an access key. Map a drive, and then copy the files by using File Explorer.
choices.D: Use Azure Storage Explorer to copy the files.

choices.A: In the public DNS zone of contoso.onmicrosoft.com, add an NS record
choices.C: In the public DNS zone of contoso.com, add a CNAME record
choices.B: In Azure AD, add webapp2.azurewebsites.net as a custom domain name
choices.D: In Azure AD, add contoso.com as a custom domain name

comments.content: Jammie-Evans is correct, answer D is wrong and should be C

discussion.content: D is not the correct answer here. The correct answer should be C - In the public DNS zone of contoso.com, add a CNAME record. Rationale: A custom domain can be applied to a WebApp without adding the domain to active directory. A canonical name (CNAME) resource record can be used, or an IPv4 host resource record (A) in conjunction with a text (TXT) record to verify ownership of the domain, and the WebApp will serve requests using the custom domain presented in the Hostname HTTP header accordingly.
the answer is C. the question pertains to webapp2 and not the need to add a domain in. thus we would be adding in a CNAME record.

questions.question_text:
You need to configure a host name for WebApp2.
What should you do first?
